name: The Crew™

The Crew takes you and your friends on a wild ride across a massive, open-world recreation of the United States that is loaded with exciting...

reviews.review_text: Well. The Crew... I honestly was dying to get this game, and I dropped the $85 for the gold edition. I figured since I loved racing games to death that this would be the perfect fit for me. But boy was I wrong. I do have a lot of fun on it but beware, the car physics are horrible and the map is sub-par at best. You get this hype from looking at the game that it's going to be awesome with a gigantic map and tons of cities to drive through but then you get in and BAM, there's only 2 cities that are slightly like 10% close to the historic scale of it, and those two are LA and New York. The problems with those are they take up 1/4 of each region they're in. West Coast: 75% nothing, 25% LA. East Coast: roughly 40% New York and 60% Hills and forests. The handling in the game is sub-par too, which I kinda braced for knowing it was on a havok engine. But when you really get into it it's one of the single most disappointing things in the game. Most of the cars either handle like you're steering them with your feet or handle like you crank the wheel over on each turn even if you're trying to only follow slight contours in the road.   +The cars are nice +The map is still nice despite the major lack of any cities between New York and LA +Bonneville Salt Flats is acutally made to a barely historic scale (only for the speed area) +Street cars handle pretty well +Circuit cars are hilarious +Circuit Silverado +HUMMER  -Miserable offroad physics because of the vehicle flipping limitations, Raid car physics leave a lot to be desired -crash cutscenes are the most annoying things ever and tend to take ~15 seconds to go away -Missions are subpar at best -Campaign is linear and not even racing -some of the fastest cars in the game are some of the slowest performance cars (Koeniggsegg Agera R: 279 mph fullstock (amazing buff), and 219mph level 1299 perf tune. Real/recorded top speed: Nowhere near any of these at 263mph) -Between LA and New York the cities are horrible and very half ♥♥♥♥♥, 90% of the giant cities that rival LA are just represented as small towns (Dallas, Washington DC, etc...)  -A lot of major cities aren't even represented in the game (Houston, Phoenix, Glendale, Palm Springs [I know it's in the game but that's like one house, palm springs is a pretty nice place], Denver, etc..) -The game feels like minimal effort was put into it. --Crashes every 1-3 hours, usually during something important like the end mission or a skill --Graphics depend too heavily on shaders and shadowing, not real effort and modelling skills. -Cops are kinda annoying but really not bad any more, updates changed the police and made them hilarious golf balls for Hummers. -Tuning the H1 to Raid spec is horrible because it tunes it like a gas engine. The Duramax LLY diesel tuned to 600hp on a would NOT have only 700lb/ft of torque, it would EASILY be in the 4 digits (around 1,150ft/lb) for torque and it would be unstoppable. Work on diesel engines, then it gets my vote (granted it's an extremely small gripe because I still love the H1 to death ingame) -Mapping is horrible, around Black Mount there are patches of trees floating 5 feet off the ground and trees growing in the middle of the train tracks that the train just drives through, and in New York the storm gutters in the tunnels underground have no collision meshes and your wheels get stuck underground if you hit that area.  My personal thoughts on this is they should put it as an early access game, not a full release game. This release is just.. For lack of better word, it's just not good, it's an incomplete game marketed as a full game.  If they announce they have no plans to do any major revamps I would never recommend this to any of my friends. All in all, The Crew pretty much turned out to be exactly what I hoped it wouldn't be, and that is just another overhyped game that isn't worth the money, destroyed by Ubisoft forcing the game developer to cut a lot of corners and release a broken game  EDIT: My view of the game went up a lot with the addition of the Mini with a circuit tune and a Ford Focus with a Raid tune (the 2 funniest cars in the game now) There were plenty of updates after that but I have neglected to mention them, but it's still not worth paying the full price for, anyone interested should get it while it's on sale.  Another edit: They fixed a lot of the AI issues, the races are extremely easy to win now if you play your cards right. The cops are like golf balls for Hummer golfing.  Still not worth the price tag, though.  Thank you for reading.  The game is getting better but it still leaves much to be desired.  EDIT: 1/27/2016 Also since Wild Run released the game WILL NOT run AT ALL for some reason.  EDIT 11/23/2016 I fixed it and it runs fine, still the same issues and fun things though. Again, not worth the money whether or not it's on sale. UBIsoft even tried to give it away.
Season Pass + Gold preorder (64,99€), still have to pay for Wild Run DLC GUD GAEM  WP Ubishit

It could have been such a wonderful game. The idea is solid, the map and community/social aspects are fantastic, but Ubi really screwed up some pretty major details.   The car handling, as I'm sure you'll read in a thousand negative reviews, is terrible. 260 km/h feels like 100 km/h, rivals and NPC racers seem to rip around the track like they're on rails, and they have absolutely no problem pushing you out of the way while you struggle to change their course even slightly.   The raid events are frustrating, as the vehicle seems to swap ends for what looks like no reason. Off road, every vehicle handles like butter on a hot skillet.   It could have been good, but I think I'm going to turn my Xbone on and stay with Forza. Maybe Ubi should play Horizon 2 and take a page or three from it.

So, Ivory Tower. A good studio. Exept, they are managed by Ubisoft, and that means problems. I have the season pass for The Crew, and it did not come with Wild Run (£14.99) or the newest DLC Calling All Units (£19.99). Now, am I now entitled to take a poo on their doorstep? The season pass only comes with the DLC's that are much cheaper than these new ones. Also the previous large DLC which was Wild Run did not support all of the cars, and the reason for the game having a mostly negative review space is that the game studio is owned by Ubisoft, and Ubisoft have a known reputation for releasing DLC, sorry, WAY TOO MUCH DLC, for a game that feels incomplete without it. It feels as if the updates for this game have been payed for and added in a DLC form, now this game is actually quite a good one, exept for the overpriced nonsense.

If you're looking for a good racing game, this isn't really it. The physics are wonky, the AI is notorious for rubber-banding (which is really noticable in the 1 hour+ 'raid' races), and online everybody is out for blood. That said, I still recommend this game for one real reason: It's spectacularly fun to just drive around.   The map is absolutely massive -- it takes about 45 minutes to drive coast-to-coast, and the best part about it is that it's not locked to where you are in the story. After the first few hours, you get a fairly hefty sum of premium currency -- not enough to buy endgame content like a hypercar, but you can do quite a bit with it, including going well out of your way to buy a car you really want.  If what you want in a car game is the ability to just drive around on a massive, diverse map, I can't think of any game better than The Crew to do it in.

Paid for a bundle only about 2 months ago or so (which cost more than 'The Complete Edition' which comes with everything INCLUDING 'The Wild Run) that was The Crew Gold with season pass and I don't get The Wild Run?! I want my money back!

I paid $60 for this game to play with my friends, then after more then a FULL YEAR of owning it, out of nowhere it suddenly tells me that my 'trial period' had ended, and they are forcing me to pay ANOTHER $30 for DLC just to keep playing? oh HELL no! thats bull! I shouldn't be FORCED to pay for DLC just to keep playing the game I payed full price for!

I enjoy this game immensly, its a great game. great graphics, great fun to just drive around and explore.   HOWEVER, I bought the gold edition when it came out, which included the season pass. but DIDN'T include the Wild Run DLC. which, frankly, is stupid. almost ALL new actual content, that would keep me playing the game for things other than just driving around, is in Wild Run.   Dropping more money into a game to get something that should of come with the season pass is just discusting business practice. though, we all know how much to expect from ubisoft.  however, don't let that prevent you from enjoying what is, actually, a really good game. I still manage to have hours of fun in it, literally just driving around exploring the absolutely MASSIVE map. even after I think I've driven around the whole thing, I have still missed spots. And you get a few good hours out of the story, so what I did buy was worth it, even without wild run.   I would buy Wild Run if you were getting it now though, because thats where all the stuff to do is.   EDIT: One other thing I would like to add, This game is what? 2+ years old now? its still getting regular updates, which is actually seriously good, especially for something by Ubisoft.

This was one of the games I was looking foward to this year. But it does so little in the areas where it matters most that it falls short of where other existing games pass with flying colors.  Sure I love the visuals of the game and it plays decently well, but the focus of the game is cars and... There's quite a lack of focus in general on them. From what I can see, there's only 40 cars that you can get from dealerships yet this game has one problem that a lot of these style of games have. They tend to favour one or two manufacturers over the rest and that leaves the variety pretty thin, especially when you only have 40 cars and around 1/7th of them are Fords.  Another thing is customization. If you wanted to make awesome murals or just a silly paintjob for your ride, I got two words for you, 'You can't'. The customization feels like it came right from need for speed most wanted (2005) but with even less content then you would even think of. I can't even change the color of my Dodge Viper since there's only 1 color for it and it's terrible.  That's another thing. Everytime I get a racing game, I make it a personal objective to get a Dodge Viper because who doesn't strive to earn their favorite car? But I practically started off with it. You can't buy it but instead, use Uplay award points to buy it and then BAM! Instant car... I already feel like I have nothing to work towards in the game now and I only just started it...  In comparison to Test Drive Unlimited 2. This game has much greater visuals and world design and also doesn't have those annoying houses that make it take forever to manage your cars. But lacks in everywhere else like car selection veriaty, customization and pay to win mechanics. Yes, this game has paid for currency in it which you can use to buy skill points that give passive benefits to your stats or immediate access to any car.

Driving and diving / Ecco the Golfin   I've grown to love  The Crew . I play it like an underwater diving game, only on land. Turn on the soapy ingame ambient radio. Dial down the engine sounds. Switch off the player tag cloud that shows which people are nearby. Mark a place on the map I want to go to. And then it's just peaceful gliding through landscapes of varying quality. Some are blander than others, sometimes the trees look like big matches stuck in the ground.  I mostly enjoy the different kitschy light situations. Sunrise, sundown,  The Crew's  sun always finds new ways to surprise me and to colour everything in different ways.  The MMO part, or let's say, the social component, seems like a total failure to me. I never saw anybody use the chat, unlike in  TDU2 , where people would often park their cars somewhere and have little group conversations that made it clear there were actual people in these cars. The only human contact I had during my 30 hours with  The Crew  was players trying to ram me into oblivion. Maybe it's my fault, but whilst  TDU2  was  The Sims  on wheels,  The Crew  seems to attract a crowd that's more into, well, driving, not chatting. That's okay, I guess. I enjoy driving. I wish more of my friends on Steam would take the plunge, but then again, driving around together could be very boring, I don't know? I suppose one has to be a proper bore to find diving-driving interesting.  I play  The Crew  to relax and the game is successful at that.
Thank God I did not buy the season pass, not worth paying that money.

So, The Crew:  Basically they took the idea of NFS Rivals and improved it, added a storyline, and optimized it better. The idea is that the game is always online. Any time you play it you will be able to see other people and even CO-OP with them.   So is it better than NFS Rivals? Two words: Hell yes! It is better optimized for the PC, more customzation, and it has an actual story line.   Some people are complaining that the map is not big enough. Well think about it - Fitting thousnds of miles/kilometers of roads and hundreds of cities into a game is pretty damn hard. Not to mention that if they did so, you'll probably get a game that will weigh over 100 GB's, and probably won't run on most PC's. So they took the best of what there is, and put it in the game.   My only complain is that the game lacks some cars, for exmaple: Subaru Impreza WRX STI, or Toyota Supra. I expected to have those cars in a street racing game. I truely hope they add these cars sometime.  And another thing, and this is aimed towards people, not the game itself: You complain about unrealistic physics in an ARCADE RACING game?! Are you serious?! An Arcade Racing game is supposed to have unrealstic physics.   If you're looking for sims: Go for something like Assetto Corsa. Because this is not a Sim. This is an ARCADE RACING game.
Dunno why people dislike this game, its so addicting. For me, its way better than Need for Speed.  Im gonna keep playing with my friend, cya :P
SOON, this game will be free at UPLAY, well,... I JUST BOUGHT THIS GAME AT SUMMER SALE... WHY UBISOFT,WHYYYY... Nice game btw

If you enjoy racing games and not just racing Sims and you ever played MCO from EA and have always been looking for a replacement this is as close as there has been.  The driving still needs some work cars float too much but overall the game will be a nice change from every other online game currently available.  1/1/15 Update  After spending quite a few hours learning and fine tuning a number of cars I've dicovered that the handling isn't as bad as I had previously assumed. Before I hadn't done much adjusting of the settings but now that I have I can deifnitely confirm the handling is fine just the defaut handling gets you off to a bad start.  I now have a 1299 car of all but Raid spec which is much harder to grind the parts on. There are certian cars for certain races. Races in the Mountain range on snowy roads are better in a Ford Focus than a Ford Mustang.  The game has alot going for it but they really need to work on expanding the Map maybe DLC's that add more cities into the map would be a quality start.   They really need to work hard on more cars ASAP there are tons of cars that could be added to this game that would really give it a lot more life. Not everyone wants a Ferrari or Lamborghini and while the Koenigsegg Agera R is an awesome car it's just not realistic to use on a US map.  Car models I'd love to see added to the game would be more upper class but not super cars. Lexus, Audi, Cadillac and Acura. There are just a lot of cars left out that the game really needs.  I really enjoy the game and there is nothing that would make me quit playing it. Weekly missions in game need to happen more often and there should be some type of end game which right now the only end game is racing other players.
loving it so far, amazing improvments from from the beta.
While the plot isn't the most realistic in how it works; the game itself provides a lot of missions and a huge map of America that never gets boring. This is a really fun game.

If I was to ever truely rate a game, Game of the Year. THIS WOULD BE THE 1 ID SAY TO BUY! no questions asked, if u love a racing game, enjoy casual driving at times, love open driving maps, then this game will be 1 of ur favourites within seconds of booting guaranteed!!!

Got to play this game During the alpha and i tell you what!?!?! They have nailed it. The game is fantastic. Im writing this review During the Beta and the game is actually awesome! The servers work perfectly and me and my friend are able to drive withing a Meter of eachother without running one another off the road or causing an accident. Its a gread social racer. It definate perks are its massive recignisable world and its ability to entertain without forcing races on people. My only complaints are the Movie Grain at night time and the lack of FOV during the in car view giving the game a lack of speed. But besides that this game is fantastic and im really looking forward to seeing the games full release. 9/10

Jacko Rating  7/10 The Crew is the first MMO to do something different and use cars and driving instead of the usual aray of fantasy characters. It is an enjoyable mix of arcade/sim style racing with the added online benefits - namely being able to join and crew up with as many as 4 of your mates to race and cruise all over the USA. Strengths are definately the enjoyment you get out of messing about with your friends whilst in your hotted up car, the graphics are good for next gen but for the PC it could be better, 60 FPS on PC runs smooth enough, the sound effects from the cars are nice and beefy and last but not least the size of the map and drivable area is absolutely massive. The weaknesses are - its gets a bit laggy from time to time, there are not nearly enough visable players online making it not really feel like a MMO (at least not yet), not enough races on offer and the button mapping system is frustraiting when trying to really customize it. The final verdict after 42 hours of playing time is despite its flaws it is an addictive driving game especially when cruising around with mates but no substitute for a real racer (wait for Project Cars). This is well worth your money if you intend to play with friends online and like a massive map of the USA to drive around but if you want a hardcore racer to post times and compete against mates then this will only annoy you. Pretty Good Game but could have been much better.

THE CREW REVIEW     Image of the in-game options  [cloud-4.steamusercontent.com]      Image of more in-game options  [cloud-4.steamusercontent.com]     Image of the World Map  [cloud-4.steamusercontent.com]     Image of an in-game event  [cloud-4.steamusercontent.com]    The Crew is not a good game.   While the concept of the game sounds great, Ivory Tower fails to execute it well. The cars all feel similar (the performance cars all feel the same as each other, the raid cars feel the same, etc) and don't control as good compared to other driving games. The game borrows many ideas from previous Ubisoft releases that don't really translate that well in a car. The online community for this game may as well not be there. There is a chat in-game but in the 20+ hours I've put into this game I've yet to see one person use it.. which can make it hard for people to find a Crew to party with in-game. Invites to races and events other people usually go unaccepted. While a large portion of the Crew relies on having a Crew, the game doesn't have a whole lot to offer for people looking for a single player experience.   The map for this game is huge and allows you to drive from the east coast of the United States to the west coast. In between are rocky mountains, open plains, wildlife darting across the road, cops, pedestrian vehicles getting in the way, little towns at the end of dirt roads and huge cities. In between all these are hundreds and hundreds (it seems like) of events. There's a handful of events such as staying in between the lines, smashing through 'gates', going as fast as you can, mountain climbing, and more. Completing these events (and other races) reward you with a score based on how well you did and are rewarded with different car parts than you can equip to cars; increasing their overall stats. Instead of climbing towers to unlock portions of the map; making you work a little for your progress, the Crew has you drive up to the satellite dishes located by a blinking aura on your map and GPS.   The story is extremely dull, laughable and perdictable.You play as Alex, a man wrongly jailed for the death of his friend. You have the chance you redeem your freedom as FBI Agent Zoe sends you information on the man who killed your friend, and she believes the police officer, Coburn, who arrested you is working behind the scenes with Shiv. You must race your way to the top, earn your ink, and take down Shiv. The music is subpar, instantly forgettable and I found a hard time finding something I enjoyed listening to in-game.  If you're interested in the Crew to get your racing game fix I would suggest looking elsewhere. There's plenty of other racing games out there that are multiple times better that'd you actually enjoy. Also, uPlay sucks.

I would say I absolutely do recommend this game if you like games like Test Drive Unlimited, and Need For Speed, that being said, there are some MAJOR downsides to this game but overall I find it a rather good game.  Let's start with the cons to get that out of the way.    -Hard to Start Out As in it's rather hard to get money for actual good vehicles. I feel as you progress more, it'll be easier but when you have to go and get performance vehicles.... be prepared to spend lots of your time grinding for money if you want an actual decent car.    -Ranked I feel as though they let you go into ranked WAY too early as I went into it (Not at all knowing what I was doing...) and was matched with the top of the top players (Platinum, Gold, Etc.). While they had level 1499 Vehicles, i sat there with a puny level 300..... As that may be my own fault for rushing it, I just recommend if you play to wait a LONG time before playing ranked.    -Street Challenges As this may just be my own personal opinion, I find as you're driving down the road, the excessive amount of Street Challenges are way too much. They typically cover the entire road, and frankly try to force you to do them. You literally have to swerve off the side of the road to avoid them... Personally, I just find them annoying as they hardly reward you anything and are quite dull, typically trying to force me off the path I was originally going.    -Wild Run As this isn't nessicarily a con to me, I find lots of people complaining since the season pass didnt include Wild Run. As I didn't pre-order or buy the Season Pass expecting it (Due to me buying the game far after the big fuss about it happened) I don't find this really a con since it's only $10 more. Though do be warned, season pass doesn't include ALL dlc like most games have it. It lacks a big item that the game basically requires and tries to force onto you, Wild Run.    -Basic Story Plot I won't spoil anything for you but, if you have ever played Need For Speed: Undercover.... This is basically that game. It has pratically the exact same plot and will give you extreme de ja vu.    -Bad Graphics... As this isn't such a big deal to me, the graphics for some things do make me laugh. The graphics for scratches are incredibly cheaply made... That's really all I have for that one... It's just rather funny how horrible they are.    Now Onto the Pros   -Long Story At the time of writing this, I am 10.3 Hours into the game, and still not even halfway into the game. It seems to be VERY long which I absolutely love, something most games nowadays seem to lack.   -Some Nice Cars There are some very nice, detailed cars in the game. Though expensive.   -Entertaining I've always been a big fan of Racing Games and I can say, this game I absolutely fell in love with. It's one game that I can actually sit down and play for a long while without getting bored, which is very few for me.    -Controls Okay, This is moreso to personal preference but - The Controls for this game is rather different compared to most games. If you're using a controller, it may seem a bit weird just to how the handling is, but I can say after a while you will get use to it. I personally fell in love with it.    I would probably rate this game 7/10... It could definitely be better, but It's still rather good. A nice relaxing game to come home to if you have nothing else to do

I have been playing The Crew for about 2 hours.  From a racing simulation point of view, the game lacks in various areas such as handling, physics, drivetrain, shifting. All vehicle handles nearly the same, with more or less understeer. Gearbox is odd, and slow while shifting/down shifting, handbraking is slow. On road, cars rarely spin out, but when pushing them to the limit, the cars will throw the rear end out, but refusing to turn. There are three modes of driving: All Assistance, Sport, Hardcore. All assistance would include ABS, Traction, steering stability, etc. Hardcore has less traction and less steering stability. Drifting is a pain in the ♥♥♥ on keyboard, but manageable on Sport and Hardcore mode.  Tuning is simplified and a lot easier for the general audience, nothing too complicated. Parts are found during runs and story events, Gold, Silver, Bronze, each adding x amount of additional car level. Level cap for players is at 50. Level caps for cars are at 1299.  From a car enthusiast point of view, for those who just wants to collect and drive the cars, and tune (not in-depth tuning), this game is great. Graphics are beautiful, damages to the vehicle is mildly realistic, environment is great. You wont be able to run over people though, just like that in Driver San Francisco, they would jump away with Level 9001 reflex skills. Engine sound effects on the cars come close to that of real cars, but only when not in cutscenes. Engine sounds from cutscenes souds like that of a muscle car, V6/V8. Collecters will still need to play the game and some events to make money, in order to mod the car. Game is Pay to Win or Play to Win.  The R34 GT-R is left hand drive, which does not exist, and makes the petrolhead in me heartbroken.  The Street Car upgrade in game gives a wheel (rim) which resembles 5Zigen Noir, which makes the Purist in me cry. Other recognizable brand of wheels (for those who care) includes: BBS (:D), HRE (:D), ROTA (D:), Volk Racing (:D) and of course, Original Equipment Manufacterer (OEM) wheels.  All Street Cars are stock height, which makes me Iacrophobic.  Game cannot be played with no internet connection, from what I've seen.  Best part about the game is that they have a replica Pike's Peak Uphill/Downhill sprint run in the Midwest. Very fun to do a tandem drifting run up/down with a friend.  Rate Game 6/10. It's not bad, but it's far from perfect. Definitely recommend for car lovers. Definitely a great game to go cruising around with friends and racing around town.

Unless you are rich like me, I really don't actually suggest this game.  If you want to get anywhere, you gotta spend money. When the wild run expansion came out, it costed like 30 bucks here and you were literally just paying for 3 new specs, a bike, a drift car, and a monster truck. Why the hell is this not free? The Crew wasn't even released that complete, and then they lock off half the cars just to milk money. The game itself is actually pretty fun, but the handling needs to be adjusted in the options, and the map wasn't the 'whole america.' The selection of cars is very little and it's stupidly small added with the wildrun dlc. This game has microtransactions everywhere, and although it is pretty easy to make money in this game, it's obvious Ubisoft is a money milking corporation. The graphics are beautiful, though.  TLDR Unless you have around 150 bucks, don't expect to get much content out of the game quickly Graphics are good, and the map isn't really the 'whole america,' though it's still pretty good.  Kill yourself Ubisoft, why can't you design a game that doesn't milk money for once. (wink wink nudge nudge Assasin's Creed annual releases)

If you like open world driving and good online racing with no fps jumping all over the scale.Then give this game a try...If anyone here remembers need for speed world this game has the same feel to it plus alot of the same cars.I completed story mode to give me alot of upgrades to use for racing online.Give this game a shot on scale 1 to 10 its a 10 in my book

6/10  The Map is amazing, a lot of details and easter-eggs. The Story is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t... but its an amazing game if you love RacingGames and if you have a few m8s who play w/ you. If you compare it w/ NfS (the good parts) it isnt a good game.

I followed this game for quite a while before it came out. I was super psyched for a racing game with car customization in an open world, something Need for Speed has not done for a while now. However, I will admit that once it came out, I never really heard anything about it. It seems like I basically forgot. Then, a friend of mine got it and I ended up buying it on sale. Clearly, as you can see from my hours, I really have enjoyed this game. However, it has some serious quirks to it, and they aren't necessarily good. So, here's what I enjoyed about The Crew, and not so much.   PROS:     The Open World  - I didn't realize just how big the map was until I really got into this game. It has, by far, the largest map out of any racing game I have played. I cannot compare it to FUEL simply because I have not played it, but it is bigger than every NFS game. And best of all? The map is  not  repetitive. You can drive from the swamps of the south to the deserts in the west, and have different scenery and small towns/cities in between. It mainly revolves around 5 major cities, and they are New York, Chicago, Miami, Las Vegas, and L.A. The developers certainly did their homework when it comes to the cities, and I applaud them for it. Even after 260 hours of gameplay, I still see places on the map I have not been, making the open world my favorite part of the game, by far.     PvP  - I find that the PvP is well done. You play in a lobby with up to 8 players at a time, who all choose exactly what event they want to do, and then the game randomly picks one of them. This includes events with any of the 5 specs. Some events are elimination, others regular races, and others a 'king of the hill' type game. What's even better is the amount of in-game money you get from PvP. Even if you get last place, you still get nearly just as much money as the person in first, and this can make it enjoyable for anyone that plays. PvP is the best way to make money, currently. However, it still does matter what place you get, since there  are  PvP ranks in the game. The higher you place, the faster you rank up.     The Graphics  - Towards the end of 2015, a free update brought in new, updated graphics along with a weather system, which also includes slick roads after rain. This is all much better than before. Unfortunately, my lower-end GPU cannot handle max graphics, however, that is not to say that the game still looks very nice on High. It now looks more like a game released this year. Also props for it being a completely free update!     Car Selection  - You can have (almost) anything, from a LaFerrari, to a Hummer H1 Alpha, to a Dodge Challenger. What I like is that the game has 5 different specs for most cars (some ranging from just 1 spec to all 5), which are Street, Dirt, Performance, Raid, and Circuit. Take, for example, the Challenger. It can have all 5 specs, so if you want to go on dirt roads with one, you hop into the dirt spec Challenger. If you want complete offroading, you go with raid. And if you want to take it to the track or go extremely fast on highways, you get the circuit spec, and so on. What's nice is that you only buy one Challenger, and as you progress through the game, you get it in each spec, so you technically have 5 Challengers.   NEUTRAL:     The Police  - I always enjoy it when there is law enforcement in an open-world racing game. At this point, I think it should be mandatory. The Crew, of course, has police, but they are only decent. Nothing more and nothing less. Unfortunately, this is where Need for Speed does something better than The Crew. During a police chase, even with 5 stars, there will never be any more than 5 police cars at once pursuing you, which by the way, are quite easy to take out. The roadblocks are laughable, since they never use anything other than the cars that are pursuing you to block the road, so you can usually speed right through them, unlike NFS: Most Wanted, which eventually has SWAT trucks that basically force you to take another route. There are also no spike strips. While it still can be fun to get into chases and have a friend taking out cops for you, I believe it could be made significantly harder at 5 stars with the use of bigger vehicles and spike strips.     Customization  - I'm very thankful that The Crew actually has customization to begin with, but it is really lacking. For one, you cannot choose from any color in the spectrum; you just pick from a preset list of colors. Second, the decals are mostly terrible. I tend to use the same 10-15 decals on most cars, or sometimes not at all, because most of the others are just bad looking and don't seem to fit any vehicle. Granted, that is personal preference, but for someone who has played NFS:Most Wanted and Underground 2, those are far superior in customizing.   CONS:     Uplay  - I think you saw this coming. I know I did. Uplay is a requirement for The Crew, even if you buy it directly from Steam. You  must  download Uplay, and you  must  create an account. Although it can run in the background for the most part, the matter of the fact is that it is extra DRM that no one really wants, especially someone like me that only has 1 Ubisoft game. It also contributes to a longer startup time.     The Story  - Full of clichés and it being overall boring, the story is pretty much mandatory in order to reach level 50. The movie-like cutscenes in it are neat, but if you are like me, you'll do the story just to get it out of the way. The fun seems to come after it's over with.     Smart Loot  - This system is possibly the worst addition to The Crew since launch. Granted, before it was added, people still complained about the grinding system for leveling up your vehicle. Now, however, it is much, much worse. Instead of what used to be a much quicker, platinum only part grind where you could go up as much as +50 spec points in a single jump, is now down to as little as +1 for the same skills. Not to mention you also have a chance of winning a customization part, such as paint, or a bumper. This makes it very hard to get your car to 1299 (the max spec level), if you weren't a player before Smart Loot was added.   Closing Thoughts  Despite some big flaws, I have enjoyed this game a lot, and I would say it's in my top 5 racing games now. The Crew, to me, earns an 8/10. If you can look past the cons listed above, I do recommend this game to any person that enjoys racing games, or is looking to try the genre in general.

Easily the best racing game I've ever played    Popular criticisms include; 'handling too much for an arcade game' Because it's not an arcade game 'wheelspin is too much' because you're using a 250 horsepower shot of nitrous in a car with a 10:3 power-to-weight ratio  Unfortunately because Ubisoft has listened to what they're hearing (ie; game hate faries on the forums) the AI has been brought down to a minimum.  Game has a huge map, probably the biggest of any open world game so far, the car handling is amazing, physics are pretty much bang-on, the in-game community is great, the car customization could use some work but it's a very small kink in an otherwise well-oiled machine.   As a veteran racing-game enthusiast (weird guy that 100%s gran turismo games) it took me almost 20 hours to get through the story mode watching every cutscene, the story is even good although somewhat generic, it's well done.   If you're an open-world racing game fan this game will probably give you a weird feeling, traditionally we saw games where you could see it, but not necessarily go to it. With this that simply isn't the case, if you can see it in The Crew, you can almost always go there.   6 levels of customization put the game's huge map to use, they are fullstock, street, dirt, Perf (performance), raid (trophy trucks), and circuit (full-blown race cars) each with it's own merits and downfalls that add an unmatched level of diversity to the game.  The options menu is even pretty comprehensive with toggles for anti-aliasing, even types of anti-aliasing. individual performance impactors with their own toggles, and full wheel support with multiple ways of customizing so you can tune it to your driving style.   All in all a fantastic game, even after the career mode there's plenty to do and fun to be had. 9/10

While the story is somewhat entertaining, the gameplay is really quite boring. There's literally nothing to do but race around, and while it is a racing game, the trailers hinted at other forms of gameplay and much more exciting cinematics. It's not a bad game, but its not a good game either. The story is pretty minimal compared to most games, and trying to tie this story into a continually running server-based platform makes for some really annoying drive times.  Also we were promised the whole country, as though that would be to scale. Nope. Everything has been scaled down so that most of the cities are a third of their actual sizes. I threw down a lot of money for this game because I thought I would be getting a lot out of it. Really, because of the setup we actually got, I say this game is worth no more than $30. If the animations and the LOD look right up your alley, you might be inspired to pay $40. But never is it ever worth the full AAA studio pricing.  ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  So now that we have Wild Run, I guess the only thing I can say is WHY didn't I get it with my season pass? Considering it adds modes like DRAG racing, DRIFTING, etc. that most racing games have from the start, I think it should have been a free update. I won't be wasting my money on Wild Run though. The gameplay as a whole is still really boring.

30 hours in and I still have much to do.   The world is so damn big and traveling from point A to point B is not boring at all since the world is full of different challenges for fast and agile cars. Upon completing these challenges, you earn parts for your car. If you don't need the parts, you can send it to your garage which will allow you to build up another car in the future.  Story missions have you racing against time, destroying crates of supplies, catching up to an NPC and making them crash, and more.  This game has car builds for dirt, street, drift, raid, and circuit racing. I probably forgot one, but that list should show you that this game is the whole package.  Jumping online with friends is as easy as meeting up at a certain location and grouping up. Most of the campaign can be completed with a friend.   Warning about DLC: 'Wild Run' is a DLC pack. You do not need it to enjoy this game, but you will occasionally run into cars and missions unavailable, but don't worry about it. I've been doing just fine without it, but I will pick it up on a sale because I definitely want this game to last even longer.

If you looking for an arcade style racing game you better play this than any of the NFS games after Underground 1-2/Carbon/Pro Street.  *Huge world with thousands of places to visit. Never race the same track again. *Open gameplay. Play the story, PVP, global tournament series, challanges, faction wars or just go and start chasing random people in the world. You chose to go single player, multiplayer or both. All in the same game. *Many different car types plus bikes all with specific race types and different strenghts/weaknesses (street, race, drift, drag, dirt, monster truck, etc) *customisation (not as in-depth as NFS UG 1-2 but still a nice addition)  If you still not sure because of the mixed reviews wait for a sale and in worst case you can get a refund, but trust me in less than two hours it will suck you in.

First of all, Use Voice chat, vent, skype TS, whatever, just communicate with people.    Probably one of the best arcade racer I've ever experienced. that's something.  Let's get something straight. Arcade racers are racing games that have selective physics to allow fun things to happen. If you are like me, someone who clocked 1000+ hours into Gran Turismo, played every racing game from F-Zero,CTR,Top gear,F1 simulators, to Racing lagoon. you don't expect anything to ever blow your mind again. Heck, after NFS after NFS, I started to believe arcade racers have nothing to deliver.  This proved me wrong. Fantastically crafted balance of doing what's expected of a racing game, and taking itself seriously without being pretentious.   > Physics  The physics are well crafted to do what it's supposed to, The hitboxes are somewhat forgiving as they will let you scrape past a crash or dodge trees from time to time, (unlike Forza where entering a corner wrong is kinda...fatal) It doesn't make you OCD about keeping your car in control like GT, and is both a relaxing and exciting experience.  > Visuals  If you have a good PC, the visuals are quite decent, the topper is the cinematic value of an active racetrack. The game is light and easy enough for you to enjoy the cranes and planes, and steam leaks, strategically placed to block you from seeing stuff ahead is a nice touch.  > Story  The storyline? I didn't care for it at first, but it started to get better, unexpectedly good for something so cliche and dead on hollywood scriptwriting theories, The characters have a lot of depth for a racing game. It demonstrates there's nothing wrong with cliches, if it's done right. The end feels fulfilling and I'd totally get DLC for some of the character side stories  The game is meant to be played together, the story is written so you can talk ♥♥♥♥ about it. It's not groundbreaking but it does the job right, something I haven't seen in racing games in a long time.  (Willing suspension of disbelief regarding 'driving fixes problems' is required. though much less than a michael bay movie)  > Gameplay  It's broken the line of pathetic cops game after game, where you can just 'go vroom vroom really fast' and get away. It's a fantastic breath of fresh air. The cops actually do something. They will stop you if you drive stupidly behind them, you react to their radio as it gives you clues when they're going to ram you, and you'll have to take risks to get rid of them (not just 'don't crash'). You can see that they're programmed to make the chase fun, forcing you to react and think of ways to taking them out, (which is not no longer a fancy dressing on a cake, it's required.) If you like challenging cops, this is going to be fun. I'm still expecting the difficulty to increase as people learn that you cant just get away by driving in a straight line. you know, the same people who ask Is it realistic? no, you aren't probably ever going to get away from realistic cops.  If you are finding it too hard, you probably aren't voice chatting enough.  The Missions are actually fun and challenging, there is enough substance in the car handling to make different skill challenges enjoyable, and the reward of making your car a bit faster after every race is great. Those crash missions are great fun, you have to plan and execute crashes giving a nice buildup to a climatic crash.  I hate catchup bonuses, But I'm going to make this an exception, It's right for the type of game it is.  >MMO  It's the best way to halt the piracy of the game, This was going to happen sooner or later, and this is a really good first step for racing games.  For an MMO, this is really well designed, I'm surprised at the MMO elements that they've got working nicely in the game, (like the RNG god) They're missing like, crafting, (Player designed parts? *wink wink*) but that's ok. but The game is well designed with so much to do for every type of gamer in the bartle test. I've found myself navigating a rocky offroad mountian climb with my friend, pushing him when he's stuck, and screaming when i was so close to getting over that rock before tumbling down. The open world is done right.  You're all worring about the cash aspect? I feel what they're doing now is perfect, Yes cash helps you get stuff, but to get the end game gear, you gotta get your hands dirty grinding the RNG god for platinum parts. so yeah, money will give you access to some cars, but any car can be tuned to the same performance tier, This is probably the correct pay model, It respects customers enough to not be pay to win, I hope activision keeps it that way.  The game is much more enjoyable with people to talk to, It's really how it's designed. The drawback is there's only half a dozen people in your session, so it's sort of an mmo with very small servers. But let's be honest, 1-- players infront of the HQ isn't driveable, especially with how much you guys care about traffic laws. )and the number will probably increase after launch day fad is over when the server is more free'  It's not free of glitches, but to be honest i'm surprised at how well it's working for a game a couple days from launch day? I'm starting to hate Activision a little less, just for publishing this.  >Sound I mentioned to my team time after time how good the Dodge Viper sounds, what pisses me off is the music, But luckly i'm on a PC, so I can just play whatever I want in the background. The sound's what it needs to be.  Tips> (Tl:dr version) - Any car can finish the game - get a crew and voice chat outside of game - accept that this isn't 'realistic' like F1, GT, and Forza - prepate a written a list of insults for the police - expect some disconnects and patches near launch date - Don't tune a 2nd car until you get 40, then buy the most expensive kit starter. - Best way to farm for money is PvP, don't grind jumps like I did. - Don't try to gold stuff unless you are stuck at a level, Platinum parts unlock at lv50. - Your mother is a nice person, okay? now stop crashing me out in PvP.

Ahh... The Crew. I must say, this is probably the best racing game I have ever played. Yes, I do have experience with racing games, as I have played NFS:UG, NFS:HP, Forza 4, Forza Horizon 2, GT, and GT5. However, I have never had more fun on a racing game than I have had playing The Crew. The Crew features a HUGE open world MMO (and by huge, I mean that it's literally a condensed version of the United States). The map has 5 major regions: the Midwest, the East Coast, the South, the Mountain States, and the West Coast. Each region has it's own main city, except for the Midwest, which has two. The Midwest has Detroit and Chicago, the East Coast has NYC, the South has Miami, the Mountain States has Las Vegas, and the West Coast has Los Angelas. Each region has it's own smaller states too, such as Salt Lake City from the Mountain States, and Sacremento from the West Coast. The map is so big I probably haven't even explored 75% of it yet.  There is a pretty large selection of cars to choose from, from a Ford GT to a Nissan Skyline R34, and each have at least one out of five specs (the starter cars have all specs, and so do some other cars). The specs are: Street, Dirt, Performance, Raid (which is basically almost monster level), and Circuit. Street is the middle child when it comes to speed, but it handles great and can take corners easily. The best car for Street is probably the Nissan Skyline R34. Dirt is for slight off-roading, as it is very fast on dirt and road, but can still go offroad faster than Street, but not much faster. The best car for Dirt is porbably the Ford Focus RS. Performance is the second fastest, and is the one you'll probably race with the most during the story. It take corners well, but not as well as Street, but it's speed makes up for it. The best Perf car is probably the Koenigsegg Agera R, Ferrari LaFerrari, or Lamborghini Aventador. Raid is for straight-up offroad and taking people out. It's the slowest, but it doesn't need a road to get to one's destination. It is the fastest offroad. The best Raid car is probably either the Chevrolet Silverado or the Ford Raptor. Now for Circuit. Circuit destroys on roads, hands down, but when it comes to offroad, you're better off just fast-traveling to the nearest street. The best Circuit is probably the Ford GT or Saleen S7.  The story is great. I had a lot of fun playing it. Play as Alex Taylor, who was put in prison for being framed for the murder of his own beloved brother, Dayton, by a V2 from the 5-10s named Shiv, and a corrupt police officer named Coburn. Travel across the U.S.A. to climb to the top of the 5-10s to get revenge on Shiv.  All in all, this is a great game. I don't think I can stress how much I loved it.
I enjoy the game for how pretty it is, the story is good, but as many people have said it is incomplete but you can complete it by buying another game.

Before I tried this game I have read all the negative reviews and was very sceptical. Its great that they made a trial version of the game, so everyone can test it. I highly recommend it.  First of all the game runs very smoothly on my gaming notebook (3 Years old now) of which I was very surprised, as its a great leap forward comparing to Test Drive Unlimited. The world is huge and the game is technicaly on a high level of detail.  First negative that stroke me and that other reviewers were writing about was the bad driving physics. The cars slide a lot that is true. I blamed the keyboard controls for that, then I have connected my G25 racing wheel and the default settings were way off. I really wanted to uninstall the game on the spot but I have made some research and found a good configuration for the wheel and I must say that the game imiedately became playable and enjoyable.  So if you have a wheel and are willing to play with the configuration you will get a nice experience, well I did. You should not expect the driving model of Project Cars, but there is so much to expolore in this game and I like many new ideas they have brought up.  It is a shame that because of bad defaults such a huge game leaves a bad taste. This game could benefit from more players become even more enjoyable. The quick way to team up with others is IMHO nicely implamented in the game.  Final verdict:  Give it a trial ! Just spend a moment configuring your controls.

There is a large number of people complaining about this issue, most likely a majority of these people, have no clue how to drive each of the specs of cars correctly. (Don't be one of these people, learn the specs correctly).  Warning, this isn't a Racing Simulator don't be like the Racing Elitest like those that are prowling the Forums.  'The Crew' does have some other teething issues, such as occasional lag during co-op missions, Lack of connectivity to other players and difficulty connecting to friend when attempting to join each others crew's (I'm from a country that the national average internet speed is 10 mbps, and the lag isn't even that horrendous for me) . These issues, are considered to be Teething issues, as the game hasn't even ben out for 2 full weeks yet, the people ♥♥♥♥♥ing about all of these issues aren't taking this into consideration, and these people aren't taking in to consideration that almost no games at launch are 100% Glitch Free / 100% Bug Free / Balance correctly / have no lag and connection between players is working correctly.  This being said 'The Crew' is actually quite an enjoyable game to play, as summarised, there are a balancing issues, connectivity issues, etc   If you are thinking of purchasing this game, honestly if you don't mind not playing with some friends or dealing with occasional OP AI pursurer/cops, then you should definitely purchase this game. I honestly don't understand the rage here. There are problems sure, but you're not going to find anything close to this game for PC, period. I'd describe it as Euro Truck Simulator meets NFS Undercover (older version, not the remake junk).  THE BAD  The 'crewpoints' or whatever they are system. Yeah the publishers have hopped onto the in-game purchase bandwagon, and I don't agree with this nickle-and-dime system outside of free Appstore games, but it's not implemented in an annoying or necessary-to-play kind of way. I'm only 18 hrs into the game and have some junk car I started out with (sorry Ford), an upgraded mid-range car, and a beautiful Italian supercar I take out on special occasions. They even give you 100k credits after an early mission, more than enough to get you started. I haven't touched the credit system beyond that, but even if I wanted to, it would be a few bucks for a new car and some random customization. Considering I got the game for 30-35 bucks, a fiver added onto that one time isn't really a huge problem.  This always-online crap is the future, and it sucks. But I haven't had connectivity problems, so I can tolerate it. The community isn't huge, so PVP games aren't easy to come by in my 18 hour experience, but I enjoy playing the missions and just crusing around, exploring. And you'll always find someone running from the police or available to ram into (sorry, I do it with love). That said, impromptu street races and roadtrips would be pretty sweet, but maybe I just need more friends...  THE GOOD  The map! The open-world! Way too much to explore! While it's not totally accurate and all-encompassing, the ability to drive around major cities in most every region of the US (Alaska and Hawaii, sorry bros) is something I've dreamed of ever since I got into driving games. And it's implemented perfectly here. Plenty of roads to take across the US, varying in driving complexity and scenery, and I never feel as though I'm trapped or limited by a wall. The exception would be the actual wall seperating Mexico and Texas. Bush wasn't kidding.  The graphics are fantastic. A friend jokes that it doesn't take much for racing games to look good, and while true, the scenery is a joy to look at. They even have a 'photo mode' because they know we're snapping screenshots. Even on my paltry Macbook Pro settings, I really enjoy looking at the game.   The handling is perfect for an arcade racer, which is what this is. I play serious racing sims but can also suspend my pretentious ways to enjoy games like this and NFS. If only Just Cause 3 borrowed these phyiscs...  THE MEDIOCRE  Rubberbanding is annoying and while this game isn't horrible with it, if your car is underpowered for a race and you make one mistake, you're restarting. Even missions where you're supplied the car, no matter the lead you have, one or two mistakes in this case can cost the 5-minute race. I've got a mission in the latter that I cannot beat, even 18 hours into the game, and it's holding me back from new missions down that path.  There aren't enough missions. This is an 'MMORPG' (MMORG?). I don't mind grinding a bit to earn money/levels. But I worry I may eventually run out of ways to advance. There are events, and challenges while driving, but that may not be enough to sustain constant advancement. I'd even settle for 'collect the tires on the racetrack' type stuff.  I love cars and customization, but there just isn't enough here. While I was able to get the two main cars I shoot for every racing game, I'd love to see more older vehicles and some of the newer supercars (why no Veyron?). I mean, why is there an Escalade and a Hummer? This isn't Cruisin USA. Give me more Ferraris, a Countach, and Porches (come on, RUF??) The visual customization is pretty bare. There are quite a few colors and they allow you to customize all of the typical areas of the car, but the choices aren't enough, and aren't significant in differences. I've got to frequently switch back and forth between parts to spot the difference. But honestly, even if I were running around in a Ford Pinto, I'd have fun exploring the map.  TLDR  All said, this is a solid arcade racer, enough cars and customization to enjoy the experience (though I'd like more), beautiful scenery and graphics, but most of all: THE FANTASTIC, FREE-ROAM MAP OF EVERY REGION IN THE CONTINENTIAL US. If that sounds good, buy the game. As of current, make sure you get the Wild Ride or whatever version. It comes with the original game and the expansion.

It's good. Really good.   The driving isn't the most realistic, but that doesn't matter, compared to what the game offers. The map is huge and feels so, too. There are no walls or borders within the map, if you see it, you can drive there. To the north are mountains in the south is the Mexican border. Inbetween is a nice mix of everything; salt flats, snowy mountains, woodland. Tuning is basically unlimited. You can keep your first car and race it in every event, you don't have to purchase new cars to progress. The selection of cars is good, too. I like classic muscle cars and finished the game with only two cars, a '69 Charger for everything but the Raid class, and a Camaro for raid. All other cars where just gimmicks for free drive. The cockpit view is great, it feels real and you have a good field of view. The music is nice, too. A good selection of tracks for all genres. You can also create a custom radio station with the ingame songs, picking what you like from all other stations.  But not everything is good, you need to be online to play. If you disconnect, it's game over. Usually not much of an issue, unless you are within the last miles of a long 1h+ endurance race.   I recommend this game to everybody who wants a good driving game with alot to do in a large world.

Well what can I say about The Crew, An absolutly fantastic Online MMO Driving Sim that has be one of the best so far. My Fiat 500 just beat an Aston Martin.  10/10 would recommend.  Now, for a more serious note:  I really don't get why this is 'mixed'. The game is awesome, it has a huge map. Handles like the old NFS:Most Wanted or something of the sorts. Yes, there are microtransactions, but you can easily manage without this, and the story's pretty fun as well. I highly recommend this game if you like racing games with an arcade-y feel to it.

Edit: After the big update it received with the Wild Run expansion, i stopped playing, because the new graphics system is a step back for me and race modes are so uninspiring and don't work well. A drag race through the city with curves? Come on!  For me, this is the best racing game of 2015! In a nutshell? It is Test Drive Unlimited 2 done right! Lots of great and amazing looking and sounding cars. Very cool classes system like street, dirt, performance and rally, an awesome reproduction of the USA, lots of varied races and missions and a multiplayer that actually works. PvP races are great fun and motivate greatly to skill ones cars to the max. Free car updates keep bringing some of latest cars into the game. Like the 2015 Ford Mustang GT, one of my favorites!  For arcade racer fans and car lovers alike, this game is for you and I can fully recommend it! The 'Wild Run' expansion pack coming this winter should furthermore greatly improve this game.

The Crew Is a game that you might love or hate it's really fun when you 1st play it but it can get a bit boring later if you kept playing alone I personally have over 500 hours on the ps4 version and 42 hours on the pc version Pros : +Huge Map +Decent story +Handling Feels a little bit realistic (you have to switch to hardcore mode through the settings to turn off assists) +wheel support +PvP Races Are really fun +It Has customizations +Good Car list +cockpit view +You can spend good Hours alone before getting bored +Super fun if you have friends to play with +Decent graphics (It'll look 100 times better + weather with the upcoming november update) +Huge Post-release support +nice easter eggs around the map  Cons : -Can get boring Alone -You can only see up to 7 other players at once -PvP Races are unbalanced -You have to grind a bit to get a decent car -dull soundtrack -FFB Is too powerful off-road. the wheel will go crazy even if you set the ffb to 1 -Cops feel off -ZERO Sense of speed -Uplay required  I give this game 7.8/10 (no that's not an ign reference xD)

Boring, braindead game.   This game becomes extremely trivial once you upgrade your vehicle at least +50 from race requirement, and this isn't hard to do.   Game can be completed with just your starter vehicle, there's hardly any incentive to buy a new vehicle unless it's something that catches your eyes (and you can afford it) or its practical and covers all 5 Upgrades.   You do not get a great sum of cash income at all. I've spent probably $4k (Crew Bucks) in total for cosmetic items like paint, bumpers and rims. By the time I finished the game I had 300K. Which can barely get you ♥♥♥♥ all.   The Crew can easily be completed around 14Hrs if you just tunnel vision your way through story mode - While upgrading your vehicle on the go. Getting to max level (50) took me around about 10hrs. The Crew's story it self was trash. It's not interesting it makes barely any sense and it's really not worth paying attention to at all. You'll often be questioning the choices made by writers who wrote the story.   The game does showcase key-parts to cities well, it isn't exactly to real size, however it does take in the important parts to places within USA.   Performance wise, it ran well on my PC on high and with 60FPS cap on (Note you can apply this within game setting - initial install its locked on 30FPS). Sometimes frames dipped within motion blur and unnecessary police red. blue light flashing on border of screen, but majority of the time i had a solid 60.   Honestly this game is decent at best, if you want a braindead game that can be slightly enjoyable and relaxing at times. But you will get bored easily.     Main reasons i pressed No to recommend game as it felt incredibly empty, boring and overall did not fill my expectations when I saw trailer for this ages back. You will 90% time be on your own and rarely EVER come across anyone online. IF you ARE keen on buying this though, do recommend buying on sale - not at full price.

For those who are curious on what this game 'The Crew'   Pro's - It's got beautiful scenery so even when your losing at least you got something to look at. - Driving can be customized/Optimized for however you drive( Google The Crew Optimization Car controll ) - If you enjoy drifting roads for days  Con's - They could have done more with variety of cars and customization (kind of a let down when they talked about building cars from the ground up) - Game received bad rep in general so lowish population -Uplay should have expressed the Optimazation for those who complain about the physics

The Crew is a good game despite the reviews and other stuff other people have said about it. It does have it's flaws, but they are far out-weighed by the Pros.  Pros: -Vast Open World to explore (Bigger than Test Drive Unlimited/Test Drive Unlimited 2's map) -Large amount of cars to buy and customize -The amount of customization is rather large -Each Spec you acquire for a car creates a new car with it's own customization. So 5 Specs would equal 5 different cars -Performance Parts for cars can be entirely earned without money by completing Skills in the Open World  Cons: -Micro Transactions -Payouts from missions and activities is low -Car physics get buggy when driving over certain features (ie Rocks/Cliffs) [This can also be fun and make funny moments. so maybe not so much a bad thing] -Campaign/Career is rather short. -You must be connected to the internet at all times when you play  These are just a few of the pros and cons. Again the pros outweigh the cons, and cruising with your friends makes it even better. I would recommend getting the game on sale or at least getting the Season Pass to save money on the DLC. This game is overall a great game. I would give it a 8.5 out of 10. It has a lot of replay value, making it worth purchasing.  Hope this review helps.

ONLY BUY IF UNDER 30$ (might be skewed, havent played in like a month or two)  PROS: -HUGE HUGE HUGE Open world -Long races can be very fun -Can run from the cops with buddies in an open world -Lots of cars and modifications  Cons: -It's a really annoying interface  -Some of the roads the developers just phoned it in, because it's such a huge map -MIssions suck ♥♥♥♥ -PVP is impossible -THe factions are dumb -Long races become pointless when you can have a worker do it for you -Getting upgrades in your car is ♥♥♥♥ing annoying, its GRINDING challenges that arent fun -Cant pvp until you have the best fastest car -Confusing way of getting upgrades in your car sometimes -AI will ALWAYS find a way to get in front of you no matter how fast you go, missions are scripted -Takedown missions suck horribly -The way multiplayer works is ♥♥♥♥♥♥, makes you feel alone among so many others  Lots of cons and can be annoying but i still think it's worth a play through just because the idea of it is really cool even if the game mechanics such horribly.

This is a really neat racing game! Other than the different type spec vehicles, I aboslutely adore the community. Most of those that I come in contact with are eager to help, and will actually spend time with you if you tell them that you're new.   As far as gameplay, I enjoy the large map, and the vast graphics. The physics; however, is something that I wouldn't give my highest rating to. (Although that's most car games I guess).  The Crew reminded me of Need for Speed before it became boring with it's closed circuit racing. It would be nice if in the future we can customize the appearance of the cars even more though! (Kinda like NFS Carbon). However, the perforance upgrades, and the variance with each part is superb! It is SO possible to have two of the same car running completely different. After all, that's realism! Nothing is ever 100% alike, and I feel like this game captures that.

If you love racing games with huge environment, get this game. And also, if you know that you need progression to have your handling get better, get this game. At first I understand why my car slips away but then through some hours of achieving rewards and installing some parts, I can see improvements on the car. Very good support too on Xbox 360 controller which makes it sufficient enough. And I love drifting so, cars that power slides, it pleases me.

SpeedYz' Review  I love The Crew. I love playing virtual tourist, driving around this massive map and exploring around with other players and causing destruction and mayhem. Have you ever raced from the Super-Dome to Met-life Stadium? Or driven from Seattle to Miami without stopping, just because you could? I love that you can also do almost every Mission as a 4-Play Co-Op,  This is the biggest surprise game is years! It is not just a great racing game, It is an all around great game! As an online arcade racer - this is fairly good. Not 'wow', but its worth buying on sale. As there are different specs (Street, Dirt, Raid, Performance and Circuit), the game covers more of the important ground of racing imo. People who love dirt and mountain climbs will like it, people who are just innit for the thrill of driving the fastest car down the highway will like it, and of course you have that 'standard' city race where the Mini's and Golf's are agile options. There's also abit of fun with the customization part with rims, colors, decals, bumpers - you name it.  The downside is the physics where its almost impossible to land on the roof for instance. Or you just fly sky high hitting a rock at 10 km/h.  Are you a racing-fan, then this is a game thats worth buying (wait for it to come on sale if you can), just for the sole purpose of the pvp-part. Actually, the singleplayer-story isnt that bad either.  Conclusion - racingfan? Yes.  Not a racingfan? Dont.

That's it Ubi, i am not buing one more game from you again. Ever. STOP RELEASING UNFINISHED GAMES!  And anyone who states that this  game  pile of crap is feature complete (or the least fun to play) must be on some powerful narcotic or something.

So, The Crew, by Ubisoft. It's a very nice idea, join friends and complete missions in high preformance cars. Sounds like The Fast and the Furious right? Joining a crew for sertain missions and for PvP is realy easy, leaving said crew is aswell. The missions in PvE are easy, even Solo. The game has a short storyline by which at the end you are the Boss (V8) of a street racing gang that has gone international criminal orginasation. You achive so by means of driving missions using various vehicles like street cars, high preformance sport cars, dirt cars, trophy trucks and circuit speed demons. You can free ride unrestricted trough the USA freely switching between cars and explore a lot of sites, the game gives in game curency as a reward for visiting sight seeing area's and provides one or two lines of background info. Also you can get involved in police chases, and hamper other players that are being prosued.  The gameplay gives of a friendly arcade style feeling. The cars look real good and tons of costumization is available. The world you dive in is done quite good and I especially like how the road surface affects your grip. Rain and snow don't do your grip any good and the various type of vehicle will respond differently to it. Unfortunatly the road does need work, small bumbs and missalignments in road surfaces cause unecpected bumbs and jumps, or crashes if using a circuit car, and cause grip loss, sliding and other automotive mayhem. Something your computer controlled opponents don't seem to be bothered by. Doing the faction missions, which only help with cashflow or so it seems, the opponents are of about the same level as you are, making for an intresting challange, if not for the unfair behaviour of the game favouring against you. Which i found frustrating and annoying at times. The game as purely a racing game gets boring quite quickly after you have maxed out your personnal level and some cars you like to use. Doing the same 'test', a mini challange, can get you rewarded with the best possible parts for your ride. The lvl 50 parts have 4 different bonusses so again, costumize and find the best setting. Making sure that cars that have maxed out still have a bit of difference in them. All sounds good right? Yes, the game in istelf is quite good, be it short, and your reasons for playing it will mostly be becouse of your friends list. Gamers are friendly mostly but crews in PvP can realy ruin your day by having one or two members take out the competions and having their friends win easy. Well within the rules but not fair play.  The game has promise, and loads of DLC is indeed promised, including more cars and area's to explore. Most will have found the Mexican border crossing by now. But at the time of this writing, is not open yet.   Conclusion, If I make the game sound in general not bad at all, why not reccomend it? Well, there's this one thing in the way of hours of fun gameing with your friends. Crashes, not in game car crashes but gamecrashes, computer crashes, network crashes, server connection interruptions, explained errors, unexplained errors, known errors that will give you a code and ask you to submit them. (the location the game suggest is the Ubi website but i couldn't figure out where to put them in.) In 60 hours of gameplay I calculated an interruption would take place on average every 3 hours of gameplay. Fairly annoying and other than the occasional lagg not very accepteble in this day and age. I don't think my PC has ever crashed on any other game besides The Crew. Save for windows update butting in but no-one can blame any game or develloper for that right? I won't at least. So The Crew might seem as a must-have, but it isn't. So even if you still want to buy it, refrain from buying it together with the Seasons Pass untill you are satisfied with the game.   So, end of rant and pardon my English! (Yes, it's meant to be English)

Something your computer controlled opponents don't seem to be bothered by. Doing the faction missions, which only help with cashflow or so it seems, the opponents are of about the same level as you are, making for an intresting challange, if not for the unfair behaviour of the game favouring against you. Which i found frustrating and annoying at times. The game as purely a racing game gets boring quite quickly after you have maxed out your personnal level and some cars you like to use. Doing the same 'test', a mini challange, can get you rewarded with the best possible parts for your ride. The lvl 50 parts have 4 different bonusses so again, costumize and find the best setting. Making sure that cars that have maxed out still have a bit of difference in them. All sounds good right? Yes, the game in istelf is quite good, be it short, and your reasons for playing it will mostly be becouse of your friends list. Gamers are friendly mostly but crews in PvP can realy ruin your day by having one or two members take out the competions and having their friends win easy. Well within the rules but not fair play.  The game has promise, and loads of DLC is indeed promised, including more cars and area's to explore. Most will have found the Mexican border crossing by now. But at the time of this writing, is not open yet.   Conclusion, If I make the game sound in general not bad at all, why not reccomend it? Well, there's this one thing in the way of hours of fun gameing with your friends. Crashes, not in game car crashes but gamecrashes, computer crashes, network crashes, server connection interruptions, explained errors, unexplained errors, known errors that will give you a code and ask you to submit them. (the location the game suggest is the Ubi website but i couldn't figure out where to put them in.) In 60 hours of gameplay I calculated an interruption would take place on average every 3 hours of gameplay. Fairly annoying and other than the occasional lagg not very accepteble in this day and age. I don't think my PC has ever crashed on any other game besides The Crew. Save for windows update butting in but no-one can blame any game or develloper for that right? I won't at least. So The Crew might seem as a must-have, but it isn't. So even if you still want to buy it, refrain from buying it together with the Seasons Pass untill you are satisfied with the game.   So, end of rant and pardon my English! (Yes, it's meant to be English)

First off I would like to say, I have more experince with this game then alot of reviews I have seen, I was a beta tester after all.   Here is what you get, a large, open, racing game that takes place in the USA. While not a perfect replica, most major reconizable areas are present, graphics are very good. The content can be realistically beaten in a couple of days if you just run and gun the story. However there is unlimited potential for VS, CoOp and Leaderboard *friend and worldwide*.   I will now address some of the falsehoods posted in a few reviews. Getting a crew, and doing CoOp is very much possible, however, I think it is reigon locked, as I seem to be unable to connect to European players and vice versa, for example. There are quite a few people playing, but depends on when you play, like any game, work, school, social events will flux the population. The game is NOT locked at 30 FPS. This USED to be true in the beta, but if you actually enter your settings for the game, you will see the option to 'frame limit' to 60. Now in my personal oppinion, 60 is bare minimum for an acceptable PC frame rate, I run a 120HZ monitor and that nothing new to the PC, so I do expect PC relases to hit 60+ without fail. Also, remember, when assessing a game, if you have bare minimum specs, your experince will be drastically different from a high spec machine, so do remember that when publically reviewing.  Now some Server stability, there have been issues here, mostly in the midday/late morning, they are not terrible, but for sure more frequant then deiserable, I suspect this will clear up soon. Uplay is almost useless for this game, now I am not a fan of it to start with, but it litterally tells you it is going to use steam to launch the application, if you launch from uplay. Good grief Ubi, just retire Uplay already.  Thats it for this review, anything else I have to say about it is purely my personal oppinion and has nothing of relivence for the game.

IDRGAF what all the malcontents say (MOST of whom are mad cause either their PC can't run this, or they live so far away from the server that it lags them)... Becasue this game RULES... it's about time a FUN street racing game came out that's got online freeroam (TDU 1-2 were full of cheating losers, NFS-World too, Burnout paradise is only fun on bikes, NFS-Most wanted (the newest one) just plain runs/controls like crud [or it'd be awesome], WOS has been in closed beta like FOREVER...) I digress this game is fun, has LOTS to do, runs WAY better then most'a the games I just mentioned above, has LOTS of cool mods for your' car's looks/performance... a list of the cars people like the most, new content coming in the future, lagfree server (I never noticed any lag really), stuff to do with your' online buddies like Co-Op missions, races, prsuits etc. freeroam chat (that oddly nobody uses, nobody did in TDU games either SMH), always online so there's other players arounf to interact with (if you want to, you can play almost everything solo), challenging freeroam challenges...
