9.9/10 Pure awesomeness.  I'm not into driving games, infact I haven't really played a driving game since Need For Speed Most Wanted on the PS2. I decided to grab the gold edition of this game because I had some extra steam credit, and god it was worth it. The driving feels really nice, and there are a couple cool types of races. There are regular street races, off road races, and raid races where you try to destroy/damage the opponent's vehicle by ramming into them. The MMO aspects of the game are awesome, It's cool seeing 10 to 15 (you can only usually see around 10 people in one city, and driving around you'll come across different players) driving in the same area as you. The graphics are very nice, and the game runs pretty smoothly. (I play at Max Settings/1080p/50-60fps depending on location. Consoles apparently run it at the same but at locked 30fps.) The map is also massive. I drove from Michigan to Tennessee to Georgia to Florida, seeing cities like Detroit, Nashville, Atlanta, Miami, and other various small towns you can encounter in the countryside. You can literally go across the entire US. (It took me 10 minutes to go from Detroit to Nashville, so I'm assuming it'd be about an hour or so to drive from east coast to west coat and vice versa.) The Crew aspect which makes the game unique is also very fun. You can team up with random players or your friends and race or do missions. Overall, It's extremely fun, and It really suprised me since I'm not a big racing/driving game fan.  TL;DR buy this game, you won't be dissapointed.

I like open world games for the freedom and a chance to do whatever whenever. I’m not into online racing and while I do complete a lot of the single player content it’s only as means to an end. Namely opening new cars and locations. The Crew is an open world sandbox with whole North America as the playground. On paper that sounds like the best thing ever.  One big problem I have with the complete edition is the DLC. As a bonus you get for free some of the fastest cars in the game and they are unlocked from the beginning. You can’t take these to beginner races and dominate everything but it does kill the need to progress. It takes hours upon hours of gameplay to earn enough to buy some of the fastest cars but since I already had a Ferrari and couple of McLarens there really was no need. It’s nice to get a Lamborghini but it’s not that different.   Even with the DLC the biggest complaint I have though is the car list. There just isn’t anything fun here! Most of it is just new supercars or American muscle cars and even those are new models from recent years.   Do you want to drive a red convertible into Las Vegas as in Fear and Loathing? Sorry the game doesn’t have convertibles. Do you want to be James Bond in one of his iconic cars? None of those are in the game. Fast and Furious it up with Mitsubishi Eclipse? Isn’t in the game. Maybe a hippie road trip in an old VW bus to San Francisco? Nope, can’t do that. Tofu delivery in the mountains with AE86? No. Herbie? No.  The open world in the Crew is absolutely humongous and it basically has no loading times. You can fast travel to any point on the map and it takes about a second. It’s insane how fast everything is loaded. The map isn’t to scale (obviously) but comparing cities like New York into the versions seen in other open world games and the cities in the Crew are much bigger. Plus there is almost an endless amount of wilderness to explore. There is no other game that comes even close. When you do jump somewhere though, the roads are empty for a while before any traffic starts to show up. Even in its fullest the streets are quite empty. You can’t get stuck in traffic at New York because there never is enough vehicles. While the scenery changes a lot and cities look different everything feels a bit devoid of life. It feels like the map was created by algorithm, not hand crafted by actual humans. There aren’t any funny little details or anything like that. While understandable in a game this big it does take something away from exploration.  Handling is arcade but I think it’s a good kind of arcade. Stock and street cars have nice feel to them. There are different variants and their behaviour is almost cartoonish. A performance car sticks to road like on rails while drift car just slides everywhere. Sense of speed isn’t very good at speeds under 100kph but going more than 200kph is really exiting. Collisions have some visual damage but it doesn’t have effect on handling and is repaired automatically after some time. Also respawning back to track is so fast that the dust from previous try hasn’t settled before you are back. It’s a really forgiving system.  Personally I didn’t feel like there was annoying amounts of rubber banding AI. For example: The cars have levels depending on their handling, speed etc. All races have minimum level and at that level you can win with good driving. If you join an AI car level 70 race with a car that is level 140 the AI will still give a suspiciously good challenge. If you join with a car that is at level 250 though you will absolutely destroy them. So the AI doesn’t scale up indefinitely. Cops and other chase related activities is a whole another story with spawning roadblocks and such usual open world stuff.   For someone who plays single player content the Crew is and open world playground without the “play” or an amusement park without “amusement”. The parks are and ground are on a technical level really worth seeing but the game lacks any soul. It’s sterile. The game runs fine and looks really good at times (The screenshots on the Steam page are bullshots). I had some issues with registering the keys to Uplay but few restarts did the trick. Without registering the game acts as trial which seems to have caused a lot of confusion but is not really an issue.   I Recommend the free trial version. It is basically full version with a time limit so do test before you buy! Many of the things i found irritating are subjective and maybe someone else who is in for the multiplayer side of things can get a vastly different experience. One thing to note is that your trial profile is the same as in full game so choose carefully which car you buy! You can’t start over.

This game is fine. I don't know why all of the whiny PC gamers are the only people to write reviews. Some of the reviews had me worried about buying it, but the worry is all hype. Some people don't have the slightest clue what it takes to develop a game. Just because you learned a few Java functions doesn't make you a developer. Games don't just appear from magic.   Now to the review. This game is an arcade style of racing. If you are a fan of Need for Speed, Midnight Club, Burnout, etc. (I know some of you can barely remember those titles), you will love this game. If you want a simulator style racing game, go play Forza. The servers are a bit haywire right now, but that's normal for an AAA title (BF4 anyone?). The waypoint GPS is one of the best I've ever seen, although sometimes the GPS takes you off road to get to hardball, but I figure it's trying to get you there as fast as possible. The rearview mirror isn’t functional (NASCAR 98 anyone?). I don't know why they didn't implement that. Maybe it will come in the future. The Gold Edition is definitely worth every penny. You get some cool cars off the bat and more to come with the season pass. If you are too cheap to buy the season pass, you still have some good cars to choose from. The guys complaining about having to buy the season pass to get free cars, refer to the 'games don't appear from magic' statement. I don't get why you think everything should be free in life. Maybe your liberal parents should've taught you better.   You crash a lot if you are going 200 MPH. But you are soon back on your feet, or tires I guess. The damage to your car in free roam goes away after some drive time. The servers stutter some, but not bad at all. It seems to happen more when I go to LA or LV, but these are two of the biggest cities in the game. Overall this game is worth it. The graphics aren't the best, the mechanics are arcade style, and the driving is fun. That's all you need. Plus it's a MMO! It’s styled just like AC games. So if you know how to navigate that map, you are good to go. Hopefully this curbed some of the worries you might have from reading the nit picking, 'I want my cake and I want to eat it too', reviews. It's a fine game... I can't praise it any more than I already have.

This game blows. Half of the missions are stupid car chases and police chases that are impossible and are no fun. They ♥♥♥♥ing suck so much and are so broke that you cant even beat them. DO NOT BUY THIS HORRIBLE GARBAGE GAME.

TL:DR: I recommend this game if you enjoy Arcade style racing. I may not like many things about the game, but the big issues, like no rear view mirrors in cockpit view, can easily patched out. I hope to see enough support for this game to see expansions like Canada, Mexico, and Europe as additional places you can go (maybe with a 10 level increase for each one released like WoW.)   Overall: 66/130  Please remember while reading this is only my opinion and I actually do recommend purchasing the game and playing.  Please don't let the low score throw you off. The driving and customization scores can easily go way up by patching Mirrors, damage, more cars and ways to customize them.   I'll start off with what it seems they wanted in this game.  ______________________ Miscillaneous: 35/40  Originality: 9/10 The spec system was interesting, Raid specs were something not really done in a racing game, and involving a purpose for them that was well designed as well.   MMO: 9/10 It's really actually good. I think it could have been pushed to that 10/10 if it forced you to group with other players for Faction missions instead of being able to solo them. I think they were afraid of not enough people queueing for 2 1/2 hour races though.  Story: 8/10 I read a review early into playing the game that trashed the story, calling it a 'typical racing game story'. After playing through it I see where this talk would be coming from, but it's really hard not to think they just skipped all of the cinematics because it was actually decent. Towards the end it got a bit old, everybody had these bad blood ties to the last boss with rediculous stories to go along, but the initial event, although obvious, was very well done. The end was also pretty thrilling as you confronted the final boss demanding a race for the V8.   Zone emersion: 9/10 Each zone really felt like it's own thing. Detroit and Chicago felt like street racing. All the dirt areas really felt like you were driving in a Rally car. When you unlocked perf spec you really feel like you did a bunch of street mods to your car. The mountain states were pretty incredible, and Raid spec for the missions there, you really felt like it was something you were doing. Circuit specs do feel like circuit speed compared to the others and there are lots of actual tracks in the game to go try it out on.   So that stuff was fine and dandy. The thing is, none of it is what the majority of people actually play racing games for. A lot of people are either Arcade drivers or Simulation drivers. This game has a middle ground, but anything other than Simulation is still Arcade, and for that most Simulation drivers probably won't like it.  __________________ Driving: 17/50  Handling: 3/10 This is because it is too easy to turn, this game has an Arcade feel where late breaking is very forgiven, and proper breaking is punished with early turning.   Speed: 4/10 It all feels very fast, but not real fast. Either the cars are tiny or the roads and buildings are crazy large, the scaling of going 65-75 mph is not even close to as fast as it is in real life, and inherently the higher speeds arn't either. I beleive it was scaled down to make the map seem larger, things take longer.   Mechanics: 2/10 Unlimited NOS (aside from the cooldown of refilling) brings this way down. Manual works well in Free Roam. The clutch doesn't seem to do anything when you have an xbox controller, can't say for a steering wheel as I don't have one. There is absolutely no gear grinding when shifting without using the clutch.   Camera View: 6/10 All the standard views, but the important one when it comes to this category is the Cockpit because it has the most detail. No working mirrors.  Damage: 2/10 Your car has a healthbar and you need to repair it, but the car will look fresh from the dealer even if it is damaged if you just drive it a bit. Damage does not effect any driving mechanics.   So the driving wasn't quite there. I don't play racing games to drive anyway. I personally love customizing, and driving slow in cool cars. I assumed a massive map where other players around the world could see my cars while a went for a slow cruise on the highway would be amazing.   _______________________ Customization: 7/30  Performance: 7/10 You get to change out a lot of the stuff under the hood. It's just a little far from realistic (being that its just Bronze - Plat LVLX peice)  Visual: 0/10 Far from the standard. When painting the car you can choose 2 tone but can't choose what part. You can't position vinals and can't have more than one. You can't customize actual peices very well, I have yet to find a car that actually lets you swap out the fenders, and most of the cars only have a couple of choices for each peice, if any.   Cars: 0/10 There are like none. There is not one Mazda or Subaru in the whole game. I hope there are many more cars added as in game purchaseables. NOT DLC UBISOFT.   _______________ Races: 7/10  PVP matchmaking and 3 hour runs for hardcores. Awesome. Starting a lot of the Story races already moving, annoying. When driving manual some of these races you have to be spamming the upshift as it starts because you start the race in 2nd at the red line.

After playing this for 131 hours I have a few things I'd like to change about my review.   The freeroam is absolutely amazing and fun to cruise around, took me a full day with few breaks to make it around the entire perimeter of the map. The police system needs work, you can go flying past a cop at speed and they dont do anything unless you hit them, cause enough damage or crash. I have not done pvp so no idea how that is. FIX THE ♥♥♥♥ING SOUNDS I extremely dislike it when my lambo sounds exactly like my skyline minus the very quiet, almost inaudible turbo spool and blow off. All the fords sound the same etc. Racing against AI is meh, if you know how to drive its easy.  Overall the game is great if you like to cruise around with your friends or do top speed runs, I enjoy playing it with my G27 wheel but dont expect to break any records in manual transmission (nitrous stops every time you shift gears) and if you're a motoring enthusiast as I am, certain details in the workshop bother the ♥♥♥♥ out of you. 2 and 3, yes 3 stroke engines. Rpm sound increases years before the crank starts turning faster, certain cars have the exhaust just floating, not connected to the engine and it comes out the diff.  I'd give it a 6/10, still recommend people to get it for cruising

I feel that this game is a waste of money at the price it is currently running. Sixty dollars for a game with very VERY poorly executed physics is not worth anyone's time. This is especially true when the game in question is a game that revolves around driving. The controls are incredibly difficult to tune and even more infuriating to attempt to execute in-game. The game has several settings which the player can change at any given point in time while playing. These settings do about as much to help the player regain control of their vehicle as a map would do to help Helen Keller navigate Detroit. From what I can tell after well over an hour of simply tearing about experimenting with the different settings and looking of their 'descriptions' on various forums I reached a simple conclusion. This conclusion is that you can adjust your settings so that it feels as though you are flinging a brick across either a frozen pond or a recently thawed puddle of mud. From what I can tell the settings allow you to either get your car to steer straight at high speeds or be able to make it around corners at high speeds, but never both. I would not recommend this game to anyone, even a person that has sixty dollars of blood money they stole from the Mafia and were attempting to get rid of it somehow. I would instead recommend to that person that they buy literally any other sixty dollar game, period.

Simply one of the most enjoyable racing games I've ever played. The Crew brings a new edge to racing by bringing an MMO style to the table. Of course there are a few things I don't like, such as the harsh handling and steering. The 3D styles of some of the cities and civilian cars could have been a bit more up to date; and the physics don't match up. You could be going 200mph and feel like you're going 120. Besides that, they blew it out of the water. Don't take the harsh reviews seriously. Those folks were expecting alot more. You have to remember this is the FIRST racing game Ubisoft has done. There are a few flaws here and there, but you will get HOURS of entertainment in this game. Get some friends to join along in the fun, and dominate. I have not played this game for very long yet, but I wanted to type in a quick review anyway because the game is on sale now. Simply put, I'm loving this game so far. It feels to me a lot like the original 2005 NFS Most Wanted and considering that was my favorite racing game ever, that's a very good thing if you ask me. It's not quite as heavy on the police chases as that game, for one, police doesn't seem to care much how fast you go, just if you crash into things. And for another, so far I've been able to pull to my top speed and they can't keep up. I've seen others complain that regular patrol cars could keep up with their supercars, but my Mustang had no issues... Maybe it gets harder later in the game, maybe those that complain simply can't drive, I don't know yet but so far I see no problem.  The game is also very big, with different types of country and lots of recognisable landmarks. I spent 2 to 3 hours driving from Detroit to Seattle, LA, then Miami (so about 3/4 around the USA). In Most wanted I used to run a race that went around the entire game area that took I believe 20 or 30 minutes.  Another thing that I think is absolutely awesome is the support for my G27 steering wheel. The game recognises the wheel on its own and all the buttons it tells you to press make sense (although it took me a little while to realise that it used the shape of the buttons to indicate which ones it meant). The force feedback is decent, but gets a lot better with some tweaking (google for the xml file you can make). The game also fully supports the clutch and H shifter. I left it on autoclutch myself because I found that when I use the clutch myself I tend to get too wild at times and my wheelstand pro will not stay in its place (has nothing to do with the game), but I really love using the H shifter.   All in all, to anyone who's looking for a fun arcade racer that still has enough sim-like qualities to enjoy it with a wheel (unlike all recent NFS games), especially if like me you keep hoping that EA will steer the NFS series back to how it played in the NFSU2/MW/C era, I can definitely recommend giving this game a try. And you can download the demo first if you want, it's completely identical to the game, it just limits you to trying it for two hours, so you can safely test it out :)  update july 2016: Just felt I should update this... The game was really fun at first, but then, it just... fizzled out? It was cool to drive around the USA, but when I actually started doing more races, it just felt boring. I tried getting back into it and I'm just not even sure what to do. There is also NO way to restart your playthrough and Ubi defends this by saying you can replay all events... Yeah, NO! That doesn't help at all when you haven't played the game in a year and want to give it another go. It just drops you right into the middle of things having no clue anymore about what's going on. And with the individual races being so bland, well, I'm permanently abandoning this game and changing my recommendation.

UPDATED!  After fiddling with FFB and The Crew's own settings, I've actually managed to get the steering up to a level that is much more realistic, give a closer feel to actually driving. This will also make you a worse driver, competitively speaking, but that's just the nature of the beast. I'll take it, and switch controllers if I need to compete for something. Sometimes FFB turns off randomly. This seems to be a handshake problem between The Crew and the Logitech Profiler software. But it works sometimes and that's not nothing.   Still, the story, is a roadblock to your progress in the game. The rubber banding the cops have on you, the ♥♥♥♥ physics (they can stop you by tapping your car), makes your success at a mission totally random. You have to luck out, and I didn't sign up for a game of russian roulette with ai. There's no tactics to the game and you feel cheated because the cops and other cars always spec up to whatever your car is. Dumb story, poor mechanics. Not recommended.  INITIAL REVIEW So here's my problem with The Crew -- I've been spoiled by Assetto Corsa. The sound, the force feedback, the realistic physics, and responsive handling of AC are phenomenal. The Crew? Falls flat in all of the above categories. The FFB is poorly integrated (no preset profiles for even the most popular wheels, such as the G27). I've fiddled around with the logitech profiler for my wheel and have successfully sobered up from Animal House wasted to Weekend at Bernies buzzed.   Visually, it's underwhelming with terrible aliasing even with TXAA at 4X. I know, it's an MMO, the servers can't handle XYZ. But damn, the cars look clunky. Where on a real car you'd see rounding in a hard edge, you just get one hard line. In short, the gist of the car is captured, but it still feels like it's a model that was made in 2008.  The cars sound like lawnmowers. There is no frequency range in the sounds -- no low frequency humming or higher frequency whining as the engine red-lines. Just a lawnmower, or perhaps a Vitamix powering up. Makes me sad.   The story, (why oh why?!) is something that should be skippable entirely. The most protracted tutorial I've been through, with most of the game kept under lock and key until you complete the story. /Spoiler/ Your brother is killed, you're framed, you're recruited by FBI. Revenge /End Spoiler/ Flat characters, not even an attempt at an original storyline. Which I'd be okay with but for the fact that my handler keeps calling me up all the time, telling me to go to the next mission. Can we just skip the story. Please?!  The HUD is somewhat cartoonish, but I understand where they're coming from. It's NFS meets...well it's NFS. But if I so much as drive half a mile, I get a pop up congratulating me at every checkpoint and asking if I'd like to re-do the past 30 seconds of gameplay. No I do not want time travel as a feature--so please stop breaking my immersion and taking up 1/2 the screen with popups. I'm drivin here!  And of course, when you buy anything from Ubisoft through steam, you have to use their absolute piece of ♥♥♥♥ bloatware Uplay. Almost makes buying any ubisoft game altogether unappealing. This is part of why Ubisoft is becoming more hated than EA. Origin is annoying, but at least it has become bearable to use. Uplay is like a horrible amalgamation of the Wii avatar system (why can't I upload my own profile picture?) and some bizzarro world version of steam, where everything is bright, white, and useless.  In short. If you're looking for a driving sim *SIM* placed in a huge open world environment, don't even consider this game. It's not what it was marketed as, and it's not what it is. It's an arcade game. Open world. Expansive. Lack-luster graphics and a bloated, disruptive interface. If you liked the Need For Speed series, by all means, go right ahead. It's NFS with total MMO integration, and it does that very well. What it comes down to is that this game isn't right for me -- a graphics stickler who likes racing that's more sim than arcade. If you don't identify similarly, disregard much of this review. The Crew might be a fun rehashing of Need For Speed. But it's also a souless exercise in making a game as middle of the road as possible.

While this game was very much antisipated by myself and my friends alike we were all severely disapointed. This game is rated as a 'simulator' and while you can run a triple monitor surround with a stearing wheel (mine is the G27) with flawless rotation and actuation time from the game to the wheel there were several, and I mean several issues that I had hoped Ubisoft could have fixed because its not very difficult to fix but they are again just being lazy.   First off it doesn't seem to matter however you tilt my wheel to barely make a turn while letting off the gas the game refuses to understand basic physics, if I tap a car that I am passing you have a chance to get randomly thrown about 50ft and turned around or flipped in a wreck setting you back about 6seconds if you get the wreck cut screen, or depending on how bad it throws you 3-10 seconds.   Second, if you are driving a Raid vehicle (one designed for extensive offroad use) you can tap a small rock and while in real life even a four wheeler could easily go over this rock without any problems your high performance off road beast gets thrown around like a piece of paper in a air cannon.   Third, the game itself isn't consistant with what it tells you that your getting upgrades on. On my Zr1 Corvette set up for circuit I can be running 220+ miles per hour and turn my wheel and start drifting into a wall which then flings me 50ft (as stated before). I go out and find a mini game get a tire upgrade and kept playing until I got a tire upgrade with a grip upgrade in a gold metal (so I should have better grip with better tires now right?) Wrong. So very wrong. While I had the chance to go to Daytona Beach and drive a NASCAR through their training course you can pay for a day of training and drive with a co-driver, I was driving at 150mph. While driving my Corvette (after my tire upgrade) I hit the circuit and couldn't seem to keep a measely 200 mph when before I was easily holding 200 consitantly.   Fourth, this is a very minor gripe but a gripe none the less, while playing this game Ubisoft has put 'Gold Metal Cars' in during the mini game challenges while driving along the road. While I can be in front of this so called 'Gold Metal Car' and have a perfect score when time runs out I will complete it with a silver metal. What the f**k?   Though there is a few good points in the game, most of the stats for the cars (stock anyway) are pretty close to accurate in real life, and while the game doesn't give you a good perspective of how fast you are driving the acceleration is almost on point with most of the real life cars as well. Given that some cars are way off on their acceleration... (for a game that says its a simulation...)   This game could have been perfect... but then agian so could most of Ubisofts games that they refuse to do because every game that comes out has to be 'cenimamatic' and 60fps 'you cant see with your eyes anyway' yet you talk to anyone who messes with computers enough and they can tell you that they cant go any lower than 30fps even on just looking at the internet. I myself cant hardly watch movies in 30fps because it bugs my eyes. So everyone do yourself a favor and don't buy this. Get yourself a Xbox immulator download (yes you can get those) and buy forza horizon if our looking for a racing game.

Got this game for free after the whole Unity Fiasco. Chose this game over Far Cry 4 and thought I had made a terrible mistake. Turns out, it's amazing. I honestly did not know anything other than it was a Multiplayer Open World Racing game, I figured it was like Burnout Paradise.  But it's actually the entire United States that you get to drive around in. Visit different landmarks throughout the country while evading cops and flying down Highway 1 at 200mph.   It's very well optimized in my opinion, ran the game on High Settings with a smooth 60fps almost all the time, never dropped bellow 53. The graphics are not mind blowing but they're pretty decent. And the transition from Third, to 1st, to Cockpit view is smooth as a freshly powdered baby's ♥♥♥ after a diaper change.  Another thing I should add is that you can take any car in this game, and compete with it against other cars. i.e. You can drive a 2012 for focus, and hold your own against a Lambo.   Only Con is it's multiplayer only. You can do races in single player instances, but you need to be connected at all times. It's pretty much a minimalistic Racing MMORPG.   Final verdict 8.5/10

This is based on the Beta as of August 25th:  I realize this is a beta and there may or may not be changes made to the things that I list, and if they have been changed after this review I will change it. That being said I'll begin my review.  First impressions of this beta leave a lot to be desired. There are a couple things that I feel that ruin the immersion of the game and give it an unrealistic feel. The biggest example of this would be the car physics and handling. I understand that they are going for a more arcadey feel to the handling, and I went into the beta with full understanding of this. However, I feel that the handling could be improved. As it stands right now, the cars feel very 'floaty'. It feels as if the cars just slide around on the road, making them more difficult to drive than expected. This could be due to the strange sense of speed, which I will explain later on. There also seems to be a slight control input delay which could be a factor into this floaty feeling. It's not much of a delay, but just enough to feel it. I don't know if it's intentional to simulate the car having some weight but I feel as of right now that it is a little too much. Bear in mind I am playing with an Xbox 360 controller, and have not tried The Crew with a wheel or keyboard.   The second thing that I noticed is the sense of speed. You do not feel like you are going as fast as you really are, which can lead to you misjudging corners and braking. As mentioned before, this probably attributes to the floaty feeling of the cars, since at higher speeds I would expect the cars to drift around. Some minor tweaks like adding more motion blur to the edge of the screen would help, even narrowing the field of view as you increased speed to simulate tunnel vision.  So far that is my biggest concern with the game apart from obvious glitches and crashes which is to be expected in a beta. I am enjoying it quite a bit in the free ride and I feel once my friends get into the beta it'll be even more fun to drive around. It seems like it has a lot of potential to be a great casual racing game, but for me the actual racing isn't as fun due to, in my opinion, the strange handling of the cars. Offroad is a tun of fun especially in Raid Spec vehicles. and doing cross country trips is a blast.  As far as graphics go, it's a great looking game, but it's not the best, which is fine by me. The damage modeling seems a bit over exaggerated, you hit a fence pole and suddenly you have a dent in the front bumper that would crush your engine block. The game is fairly well detailed especially in the customization. You can strip your car down and see the internals of your engine and gearbox, which while it isn't necessary, it is nice to see them putting in extra detail.  There is a ton of customization options as far as body kits and rims. I love the fact that they added offical rims to the cars, instead of generic rims (which can still be used if you'd like). There are tons of bumpers, side skirts, hoods, and spoilers to choose from, although some of the bumpers do seem so much alike I couldn't tell a difference.  Overall if I had to I suppose I would recommend the game, but not by much. The potential is there, but it does seem to be lacking in some areas and even though it's a beta there's no guarantee that these things will improve. If you haven't preordered it yet, just wait and see how the reviews are after release. To me it's not preorder worthy, and I may ask for a refund by the end of this beta and wait and see.

This game is a bad racing game but a great open world exploration game. The physics are wonky and inconsistent, controlling your car is a pain, and opponents regularly cheat making races seem unfair. However, I bought the game for the sole purpose of driving around America and I was not dissapointed. If you are like me and really enjoy driving around in GTA and Watch_Dogs just exploring then you will love the Crew. After only two easy quests you can take off on epic roadtrips across America. There's a wide variety of areas to explore and I have barely touched the surface of the world open to explore. Don't get too excited for great racing gameplay, or next gen graphics but do be ready to explore a huge open world with friends.

Garbage game. Don't buy it unless it's at least 50% off. This could have been a really great and fun game but it's sold in a beta state and Ubi/Ivory Tower are releasing patches that doesn't fix anything.  If you liked TDU, you could like this game.  Pros: - gigantic map, different landscapes, a pleasure to visit and cruise - quite great lifespan, there's no real 'end' even if you can quite quickly complete main story - nice personal XP and car level to improve performance and tuning - little but great panel of cars (american, european, asian) - quite good panel of races (even if some types of races are quite similar) - music choice  Cons: - 100% online - Playing alone or w/ friends is just the same since the missions aren't designed differently alone or with 3 friends - While in a crew, nearly 50% of the time you will not be rewarded for finishing some races because you got randomly 'disconnected' from the server - nice after an hour of driving - Sometimes you will see your friend offline ingame and you won't be able to play w/ them, even during some races. You have to quit and relaunch the game - Statistics and awards reseting randomly each two days - means you get less money per day - FF/FR/4WD : no feeling difference between them, they all act like some old FR - Engine sounds could be way better - Awful physics engine (bad management of crashes, collision bugs) - Sometimes cars are just randomly breaking, nice during a 1 hour race to lose just because it looks like your controller is stuck on the brake button - Good driving non rewarded b/c of the IA getting some kind of unlimited nitro so you can't escape them and get more than +0:02 - Bad driving non punished b/c of the IA waiting for you during a race if you're behind - Police cars : 80s Ford able to chase in straight line w/o difficulty a 900 BHP BMW M5 cruising @ 250+mph - Some DLC are unavailable - Ubisoft/Ivory Tower fixes that doesn't fix anything   This could have been a really great game if the IA wasn't so stupid and killing all the fun in the game w/ the bugs you encounter while playing in group. Wait for a 50% discount or some serious fixes, or go if you were a great fan of the TDU series and you wish to only play alone.

Game is great, Story line and leveling is full of content but most the time you will just want to do this single player to get to 50. Also just exploring around the areas for different landmarks that make up the vast map of the USA.  It is quite challenging and I would not like to be using just a keyboard as you need to weave in and out of traffic and its a fine controll that is needed. The missions sometimes take up to 10 tries to complete sometimes 15 or 20 times on the harder ones but you will eventually get there after repeating it over and over that you will progress to 50.  50 is where the long long long races start. PVP would also be good on these long 'faction missions' and you are just rewarded for completing the race in most cases. I just finished a 1h 30min race around the circumferance of the USA on all the highways and had enough funds then after I had been saving to buy a lamborghini. Now i need to go around earning parts for it. Each faction mission you complete earns you reputation and you progress through this at end game.  I feel the crew is a good to great game that will keep you buisy for a long time and it doesnt reallly get that boring if you pace yourself through the content, Microtransactions dont matter as you can get everything by just playing the game, but if you want to spend some real dollars on perks and buing a car well then why not hey. but its not pay to win and you can EASY get the cars with a bit of effort  Graphics are AMAZING at 4k and it runs at a good framerate, I turned the music off but the car SFX are awsome too.  Even though there is 8 players viewed at a certain time the game cycles through the whole pool of players to whoever is closest to you so you never feel alone, quite regualarly they invite you to a game, single or multiplayer is fun in this game.  It may be worth getting the gold version of this game as it includes the McClaren car that helps with getting to 50  I have and still am enjoying the crew, there will be content patches so it could last another year of play.

The Crew is a very good game, first off i would like to begin by saying that i have found multiple errors with the game such as:  The radio in the game is absolutely terrible!  Lack of character voice context during story game-play same 2-3 sentences said over and over again.  Some cut-scenes lag: Rear end of the car jumps around during a lot of them when the camera is close up.  Customization features are lacking even compared to some older more rubbish games e.g Need for speed undercover I have used this game because it did lack in a lot of customization features but i did find that in someways due to the age difference, the crew could have implemented a lot more customization feature. (Need for speed underground and underground 2 would not have been a fair comparison as there were way too many customization features in those games and they would have beaten this game hands down in this aspect.)   When you quit the game it does freeze when it is loading down and if i pressed the windows key the screen would remain black but i would have the taskbar at the bottom, they are releasing a major update soon as i did contact them about this problem because the only way i could actually get rid of this to use my desktop is if i did Ctrl+Alt+Del then signed out so i could sign back in again or restarted the computer using the restart button on my case.  i have had a couple of other problems of which i have told they about so they should look into sorting them out as soon as they can.  The Non Errors about this game is that:  It has amazing graphics.  You can run it at a stable frame-rate (i run it at 40-60 fps.)  The challenges are actually quite good.  The cars are stable and run very well.  The map is absolutely massive it took me ages just to get across a little bit.   I have many positive views about this game alot more than i do negative views, if you like racing game i would recommend this game it is very fun. If you do not like waiting for stuff or unlocking stuff this is not the game for you, luckily for me i do like that so this game is for me. There are so many different aspects of this game that you have to take into consideration and once you do, you really can see the inner beauty.

I can no longer play the game. I get a message saying that it stooped working every time I try to play it now. I would be more upset about it if it was a game that is worthwhile, but the little bit of it that I have played was not that fun anyway. I don't think I will be buying any more games from Ubisoft.

So far it's a great game. The biggest thing I don't like is that it constantly uses the internet, so if you do not have internet, or do not have a stable, constant connection, DO NOT BUY IT. Otherwise, if you have a bandwidth limit, beware when playing this game for a long period of time. This game also will send you back to the main menu if you lose your internet connection. The story in the game so far is good. I won't give any spoilers. There are plenty of cars in game, but you must earn a lot of in-game cash to be able to buy them. Car customization could be better, but this game isn't a simulation, so I didn't expect engine swaps, turbo/supercharger add-ons, etc. What's really cool is how you can modify cards for street, track, dirt, etc. One thing that bugs me is that the car sounds don't change when you switch said modification classes. For example, the Dodge Charger still sounds like the stock engine in a dirt/rally config. I did noticed when I upgraded the Skyline R34 from street to circuit version (R34 GT3), you do hear the transmission whine as you do in a race car. Kudos for that.  If you've never played this game, I should mention it is an open world like some of their other games (Far Cry, Assassin's Creed). You can drive from New York to Miami to LA, etc. Of course, it doesn't take as long as it does in real life (which is good), but it's a very neat touch Ubisoft added in for a racing game, and I hope other game makers use this as a template for street-oriented racing games.
